item.content:encoded: New research led by @PaulMaarten @erasmusmcintl @MolecularGenet3 in collaboration w/@AICJanelia uses 3D tracking & super-resolution microscopy to reveal the distinct mobility patterns of molecules that help prevent cancer by repairing damaged DNA. üßµ 1/7 https://t.co/bunxVnHVIS https://t.co/fnzq4YZqd2

item.title: üß¨ The new study looks at the BRCA2 protein, which is essential for repairing DNA lesions. Mutations in the BRCA2 gene, which produces the BRCA2 protein, can result in the protein not functioning properly and can lead to an increased risk of developing breast & ovarian cancer.2/7
item.description: üß¨ The new study looks at the BRCA2 protein, which is essential for repairing DNA lesions. Mutations in the BRCA2 gene, which produces the BRCA2 protein, can result in the protein not functioning properly and can lead to an increased risk of developing breast & ovarian cancer.2/7
item.content:encoded: üß¨ The new study looks at the BRCA2 protein, which is essential for repairing DNA lesions. Mutations in the BRCA2 gene, which produces the BRCA2 protein, can result in the protein not functioning properly and can lead to an increased risk of developing breast & ovarian cancer.2/7

item.title: ‚ùì BRCA2 must act in the right place & right time to repair DNA, so understanding its behavior is important for understanding its function. BRCA2 accumulates at sites of DNA damage, but it was unclear how the proteins moved & organized themselves at these sites when needed.3/7
item.description: ‚ùì BRCA2 must act in the right place & right time to repair DNA, so understanding its behavior is important for understanding its function. BRCA2 accumulates at sites of DNA damage, but it was unclear how the proteins moved & organized themselves at these sites when needed.3/7
item.content:encoded: ‚ùì BRCA2 must act in the right place & right time to repair DNA, so understanding its behavior is important for understanding its function. BRCA2 accumulates at sites of DNA damage, but it was unclear how the proteins moved & organized themselves at these sites when needed.3/7

item.title: üî¨ The new research used aberration-corrected multifocal microscopy, or acMFM, and 3D single-molecule tracking to quantify the motion of BRCA2 at DNA damage sites and in the nucleus. 4/7
item.description: üî¨ The new research used aberration-corrected multifocal microscopy, or acMFM, and 3D single-molecule tracking to quantify the motion of BRCA2 at DNA damage sites and in the nucleus. 4/7
item.content:encoded: üî¨ The new research used aberration-corrected multifocal microscopy, or acMFM, and 3D single-molecule tracking to quantify the motion of BRCA2 at DNA damage sites and in the nucleus. 4/7

item.title: The new research finds a large fraction of BRCA2 molecules near DNA damage sites are immobile, while some molecules show restricted motion near these sites, potentially providing a mechanism for how the cell can retain an increased number of molecules at DNA repair sites. 5/7 https://t.co/eLAoVQS2YK
item.description: The new research finds a large fraction of BRCA2 molecules near DNA damage sites are immobile, while some molecules show restricted motion near these sites, potentially providing a mechanism for how the cell can retain an increased number of molecules at DNA repair sites. 5/7 https://t.co/eLAoVQS2YK
item.content:encoded: The new research finds a large fraction of BRCA2 molecules near DNA damage sites are immobile, while some molecules show restricted motion near these sites, potentially providing a mechanism for how the cell can retain an increased number of molecules at DNA repair sites. 5/7 https://t.co/eLAoVQS2YK

item.title: ü¶† The research also finds BRCA2 molecules form nanoscale clusters at specific locations within the DNA damage sites, suggesting there may be multiple sub-compartments at the chromatin surrounding these sites. 6/7
item.description: ü¶† The research also finds BRCA2 molecules form nanoscale clusters at specific locations within the DNA damage sites, suggesting there may be multiple sub-compartments at the chromatin surrounding these sites. 6/7
item.content:encoded: ü¶† The research also finds BRCA2 molecules form nanoscale clusters at specific locations within the DNA damage sites, suggesting there may be multiple sub-compartments at the chromatin surrounding these sites. 6/7

item.title:
Overall, the new findings contribute to scientists‚Äô understanding of how nuclear proteins organize in the nucleus to control essential processes, and how BRCA2 gets to DNA lesions to repair DNA when it is needed. 7/7
Read the preprint @biorxivpreprint: https://t.co/bunxVnHVIS

@PCI_RegReports It provides a blueprint for how you can use @PCI_RegReports as a vehicle for getting a programme of work that will lead to multiple outputs (as RRs) peer-reviewed & accepted in advance through a single integrated review process.
It includes two key features:
item.description:
@PCI_RegReports It provides a blueprint for how you can use @PCI_RegReports as a vehicle for getting a programme of work that will lead to multiple outputs (as RRs) peer-reviewed & accepted in advance through a single integrated review process.

item.content:encoded: @PCI_RegReports It provides a blueprint for how you can use @PCI_RegReports as a vehicle for getting a programme of work that will lead to multiple outputs (as RRs) peer-reviewed & accepted in advance through a single integrated review process. It includes two key features:

item.title:
The first is *scheduled review*, where the review process is planned in advance & the recommender lines up your reviewers while you're writing the Stage 1 manuscript https://t.co/DKLjZSgkP8
It's a big time saver, reducing Stage 1 review time enormously w/o compromising quality

item.title:
If you choose a PCI RR-friendly journal then your RRs will be accepted immediately without further review. https://t.co/Uwm8DNY6FB
It's win for science. Compared to peer review managed by publishers: more efficient, same or higher quality, more options, more control. And free.
